Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
Cubic bismuth pyrochlores in the

Nb 2

$\mathrm{Nb}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{5}$ system have been investigated as promising dielectric materials due to their high dielectric constant and low dielectric loss. Here, we report on the dielectric properties and microstructures of cubic pyrochlored
Bi 1.5
MgNb 1.5
O 7
$\mathrm{Bi}_{1.5}\mathrm{MgNb}_{1.5}\mathrm{O}_{7}$ (BMN) ceramic samples synthesized via solid-state reactions. The dielectric constant (measured at 1 MHz) was measured to be
∼ 120
${\sim}120$ at room temperature, and the dielectric loss was as low as 0.001. X-ray diffraction patterns demonstrated that the BMN samples had a cubic pyrochlored structure, which was also confirmed by selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns. Raman spectrum revealed more than six vibrational models predicted for the ideal pyrochlore structure, indicating additional atomic displacements of the A and
O ′
$\mathrm{O}'$ sites from the ideal atomic positions in the BMN samples. Structural modulations of the pyrochlore structure along the [110] and [121] directions were observed in SAED patterns and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images. In addition, HR-TEM images also revealed that the grain boundaries (GBs) in the BMN samples were much clean, and no segregation or impure phase was observed forming at GBs. The high dielectric constants in the BMN samples were ascribed to the long-range ordered pyrochlore structures since the electric dipoles formed at the superstructural direction could be enhanced. The low dielectric loss was attributed to the existence of noncontaminated GBs in the BMN ceramics.

The pyrochlore oxide families are fascinating multifunctional materials because A and B sites can be occupied by a broad range of elements that can lead to a great variety of physical properties, such as dielectric, magnetic, optical, and catalytic properties [1]. These properties could be controlled by parameters such as ionic sizes, polarizabilities of the ions, and electronic configurations. The ideal pyrochlore structure can be considered as an ordered defect fluorite structure with twice the lattice constant, and this crystal structure can tolerate vacancies at A and O sites to an extent allowing the migrations of cation and anion. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), which can directly image the structural displacive disorder and/or structural defects at the atomic scale and determine the microstructures at atomic scale in real space, is proved to be invaluable in characterizing the local structures. In addition, in reciprocal space, selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern is another extremely useful tool for local nanoscale structural characterization as a result of its sensitivity to weak features of reciprocal space, in particular to structured diffuse intensity distributions arising from local compositional ordering and associated displacive structural relaxation.

In this work, cubic pyrochlore-typed BMN ceramics were synthesized by solid-state reactions, and their dielectric properties and microstructures were investigated by dielectric impedance spectroscopy, x-ray diffraction (XRD), SAED, Raman spectra, and HR-TEM. The dielectric constant (measured at 1 MHz) was found to be
∼ 120
${\sim}120$ at room temperature, and the corresponding dielectric loss was as low as 0.001. The XRD patterns demonstrated that the synthesized BMN samples had a cubic pyrochlore-type structure, which was also confirmed by SAED patterns. More than six vibrational modes were revealed in the Raman spectra of BMN samples, indicating the existence of additional atomic displacements of the A and
O ′
$\mathrm{O}'$ sites in the BMN samples. The local nanoscale structural information of the synthesized BMN was revealed by both HR-TEM images and SAED from the real and reciprocal spaces, which enabled a better understanding of the local structural origin of dielectric polarization and electric-field dielectric tunability.

After drying at 120 °C, the mixed powders were ground, then pressed into disc shape and presintered at 800 °C for 2 h in air. Subsequently, the presintered disc samples were ball-milled again for 24 h to get crushed powders. After drying, the crushed powders mixed with 5 wt.% polyvinyl alcohol binders were pressed into cylindrical pellets with a diameter of 10 mm and thickness of about 2 mm. Disk pellets were sintered at 1000 °C for 4 h. To measure the dielectric properties, the specimens were electroded with postfired silver paste on both sides. The dielectric properties of the sintered BMN ceramics were measured as functions of frequency using an HP4192A impedance analyzer controlled by a computer. The phase structures of the sintered BMN pellets were examined by XRD (Philips X’Pert MRD four-circle diffractometer) using CuK
α
$\alpha$ radiation. The scanning rate was 0.02° per second, and the
2 θ

To obtain the structural information of the BMN ceramics from vibrational spectra, Raman scattering investigations were also performed at room temperature with a Jobin Yvon HR800 spectrometer (JY Ltd., France) and visible laser light (wavelength 514.5 nm) as the excitation source. The slits were adjusted so that the resolution was 1 cm−1. The grain morphology, crystal lattice structures, and grain boundary structures were examined by a field-emission TEM (FEI, Titan S/TEM, operated at 300 kV). Specimens for TEM observations were prepared by mechanical polishing to
∼ 30

Bright-field TEM image of typical grains in the BMN ceramic samples is shown in Fig. 4(a). It is observed that the grains basically have rounded grain boundaries, indicating that the grain growth occurred as normal grain growth mode during the sintering process. The average grain size of the BMN ceramics was measured to about 0.50 μm. The grains contacted tightly each other, and the grain boundaries (GBs) were much clean. Especially, the triple-grain boundaries were also very clean, and no any segregation or impure phase was observed at these GBs. Figure 4(b) displays a typical TEM image of a triple-GB, which was formed by grains a, b, and c. The atomic-scale microstructure of such a triple-GB was revealed by HR-TEM image, as shown in Fig. 4(c). Clearly, the lattice fringes are observed within the grains a, b, and c. The GBs between grains a, b, and c are atomic-scale clean; therefore, no any segregation or impure phase was observed in the triple-region. Such a triple-GB is benefit to reducing the extrinsic dielectric loss of the BMN ceramics, thus, improving the dielectric properties of the BMN ceramics. The single crystalline nature of the BMN grains was also confirmed by the HR-TEM images taken from individual grain a and b, as shown in Figs. 4(d)–(e). All the HR-TEM images clearly reveal two-dimensional lattice fringes along different directions (as marked in Figs. 4(d)–(e), indicating well-developed atomic arrangements in the BMN ceramics. The SAED patterns shown as insets in Figs. 4(d)–(e) also demonstrated that the grains had a single-crystalline nature, and their lattice constants determined from the SAED patterns matched well with that from XRD analysis. It was also noticed that a superstructure along the [110] direction was observed in the HR-TEM image (Fig. 4e) taken from grain b. The lattice fringes of the HR-TEM image along the [110] direction were examined to be 0.72 nm, close to the (110) lattice spacing of the pyrochlore structure of BMN (
a = 1.052
nm
$a = 1.052\ \mbox{nm}$ ). This superstructure was also confirmed by the weak superlattice diffraction spots in the SAED pattern (bottom-right corner), which were indicated by white arrows. Besides the superstructure observed in [110] direction, an additional complex structural modulation of the pyrochlore structure along the [121] direction was also observed in the electron diffraction pattern and HR-TEM image, as shown in Fig. 5. The modulated periodicity was measured to be equal to six lattice distances of (242) planes, as shown in Fig. 5. Therefore, this modulated structure can be described by a six-fold periodicity along the [121] direction, which was also confirmed by the related SAED pattern (see the inset at top-left corner in Fig. 5). The corresponding FFT pattern of the HR-TEM image was also shown as the inset at bottom-right corner in Fig. 5, which demonstrated the periodically modulated structure of the cubic pyrochlore structure. The above structural modulations observed in the HR-TEM images of BMN suggest a subtle breaking of the cubic symmetry. It is also noted that the symmetry constraints for the ideal cubic pyrochlore structure (with space group Fd3m), forbid the appearance of
{ 100 }
$\{100\}$ ,

$\{200\}$ reflections. The first two are absent due to the consequence of the F centering, and the latter one was attributed to the diamond glide. However, in the present experimental SAED patterns, the diffraction spots of (110) and (242) are still visible, which violate special reflection conditions for the 8b, 16c, 16d, and 48f sites occupied in the ideal arrangement [15]; these observations imply that some of the atoms are displaced to lower symmetry positions. That is the reason why more than six Raman vibrational models (predicted for the ideal pyrochlore structure) are observed in the present BMN samples.

In contrast, superstructures (or modulated pyrochlore structures) along the [110] and [121] directions are clearly revealed by HR-TEM images, which indicates that the A-cations and the

The low dielectric loss in the present BMN ceramics can be ascribed to the existence of purified GBs, which is an added benefit to reducing the extrinsic dielectric loss.

Section1.Heading: Summary
Section1.Para:
In this work, BMN ceramics with a cubic pyrochlore structure were synthesized by solid-state reactions, which exhibited low dielectric loss of 0.001 and high dielectric constant of 120 at 1 MHz. Both x-ray diffraction and selected area electron diffraction patterns demonstrated that the BMN ceramics had a cubic pyrochlored structure, and the single crystalline nature of the BMN grains was also confirmed by the HR-TEM image and SAED patterns taken from individual BMN grains. TEM images revealed that the BMN grains had a spherical grain morphology, and the atomic-scale grain boundary structures revealed by HR-TEM images demonstrated that the GBs in BMN samples were very clean, and no any segregation or impure phase was observed at GBs. More than six vibrational models revealed by Raman spectra indicated the existence of additional atomic displacements of the A and
O ′
$\mathrm{O}'$ sites from the ideal atomic positions in the pyrochlore structure. Modulated cubic pyrochlore structures along the [110] and [121] directions were revealed by SAED pattern and HR-TEM images, which are likely responsible for the high dielectric constant of the BMN samples. The low dielectric loss was closely related to the existence of the clean GBs in the BMN ceramics.
